summary: William D. Campbell was an FBI Special Agent. The documents indicate his involvement in FBI investigations, specifically related to Martin Luther King Jr. and electronic surveillance activities. He was interviewed by the Senate Select Committee (SSC) regarding these investigations. The documents also mention the FBI's response to requests from the U.S. Senate Select Committee on Intelligence Activities (SSC) for materials related to Martin Luther King, Jr., and the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, suggesting Campbell may have been involved in providing information or materials to the committee. There is a pattern of his involvement in investigations and providing information to Senate Select Committees.
significance: Based on the provided documents, William D. Campbell's significance in the JFK context is indirect. The documents focus on his involvement in FBI investigations related to Martin Luther King Jr. and electronic surveillance, as well as his interactions with Senate Select Committees. While these investigations and committee activities may have tangential connections to the broader context of intelligence activities during the JFK era, the documents do not explicitly link Campbell to the JFK assassination.
